soap_summary:
## SUBJECTIVE
- The patient presented with a 56-year-old male complaining of a dull pain on the right back and a swelling in the same area for several weeks [CN_77465_0, CV_77465_3, CF_77465_1]. He reported being in good state and very active [CN_77465_0, CV_77465_2, CF_77465_2]. He had a previous simple fracture of the 9th right rib one year ago [CN_77465_0, CV_77465_3].

## OBJECTIVE
- A CT scan revealed a tumor of the thoracic wall in the right hemithorax measuring 8 x 4 cm with heterogeneous density [CF_77465_1].
- Micronodular infiltrations were seen in both lungs up to 5mm in diameter, and a single nodule of almost 1cm in the lower lobe of the right lung [CF_77465_2].
- Frozen biopsy of the lung lesions and an excision biopsy of the thoracic wall tumor were performed [CF_77465_3, CF_77465_4].
- The biopsy results were negative for malignant cells [CF_77465_4].

## ASSESSMENT
- The patient presented with a malignant tumor of the thoracic wall with secondary lesions in both lungs [CF_77465_3].

## PLAN
- Oncologic resection of the tumor of the thoracic wall was performed [CF_77465_4]. The patient was discharged in very good condition five days after the procedure [CF_77465_6].  Information needed: Further follow-up to monitor for recurrence [Not documented].
